awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Modular Origami in Soft Robotic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project studies new ways to engineer specified mechanical properties into soft robots. Soft robots are intelligent machines with a highly compliant physical structure -- that is, the body of the soft robot will bend when relatively small forces are applied to it. High compliance makes soft robots much safer around people than traditional rigid robots, and also allows soft robots to attain a variety of shapes and to move in many more ways than robots with only a small number of discrete joints. Because structures that are easy to bend cannot carry large loads, a major challenge in soft robotics is to create variable-stiffness structures that are compliant only in certain directions, or only at specific times. This project presents a new approach to engineering variable-stiffness soft robots, inspired by the art and science of "origami," or paper folding. Origami-inspired soft robots use thin sheets of relatively stiff materials that are made bendable along designated fold lines; the folding pattern can be used to create very precise and complex equivalent mechanical properties. This engineered flexibility contrasts with soft robot structures made of materials such as rubbers and foams, which are limited in their achievable strength by the intrinsic softness of the material itself. In this project, origami-inspired folding patterns are used to create modules with a specified compliant behavior. Larger and more capable robots can then be built up by combining many such modules. Examples of the potential of modular origami-inspired robots include soft tentacle-like manipulation in confined spaces, whole-body and passive conformal grasping, and controllable shape change. The results of the project will advance the national health and prosperity, by enabling origami-inspired soft robots to be used in homes, hospitals, and manufacturing sites, as care-givers, co-workers, and self-morphing structures. Educational activities integrated with this project will use origami-inspired robots as teaching tools for students of all ages through outreach activities, high-school internships, and undergraduate projects. 

This project will establish modular and scalable design and fabrication methods, characterize and model mechanical properties, and test control algorithms for lightweight origami-inspired modular continuum soft robots to intelligently perform manipulation, grasping, and shape-change tasks. A comprehensive integrated research and education plan will address (1) modular origami design, fabrication, and modeling, to study the mapping between mechanical properties of origami-inspired modules and their design/fabrication parameters, electrically addressable actuation using distributed tendons, distributed soft sensing of 3-D deformation and external forces, and computationally efficient clothoid formulation of continuum section deformations under external loads for dynamic modeling; (2) Control methods that endow soft robots with intelligence, to enable safe force/position interaction with the environment, synergistically combining motion planning and control at the state space, and hyper-redundancy of large scale modular systems to morph into desired shapes with minimal actuation and sensing requirements. Results will be evaluated through validation case studies in continuum arm manipulation, whole-body wrapping and utilizing conformal contact for grasping, and shape change and stiffness control by very large degree-of-freedom origami actuation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on advancing the field of soft robotics through the development of modular origami-inspired robotic systems. Unlike traditional rigid robots, soft robots leverage elasticity to achieve continuous deformation, adaptability, and safety in interaction with their environments. This research explored novel design and control paradigms to enhance the functionality and scalability of soft robotic systems, with applications ranging from manipulation to mobility in complex and cluttered spaces.

The project introduced a modular architecture for soft robotics, enabling seamless integration of actuation, sensing, and control. By utilizing origami-inspired geometric patterns, the research engineered elasticity through design rather than relying solely on material properties. This approach facilitated the development of robotic modules with tunable mechanical properties, such as anisotropic stiffness, and capabilities for precise motion and obstacle avoidance.

Control algorithms were another cornerstone of the project, with significant advancements made in real-time inverse kinematics for redundant extensible continuum robots. The Analytical Model-Based Real-Time Posture Heuristic (AMoRPH) inverse kinematics solver, developed during this project, enabled smooth, precise, and real-time control of modular extensible continuum robot arms. This work provided a critical foundation for deploying these systems in high-dimensional robotic structures and task-specific configurations.

The project also expanded the application space of soft robotics by designing mobility systems inspired by biological forms. These included lizard-inspired robots for confined spaces and fish-like deformable tails and bodies with origami-inspired 3D-printed wavespring and bellows structures for underwater propulsion that enhanced maneuverability. These designs demonstrated the versatility of soft robotics in addressing challenges posed by diverse environments and tasks.

In addition to technical contributions, the project emphasized education and outreach. By incorporating research findings into graduate and undergraduate curricula, mentoring diverse groups of students, and engaging with the community through outreach programs, the project made a lasting impact on workforce development and STEM education. The educational developments and outreach activities performed as part of this project promise to open up new opportunities for cohesive and collaborative environments to inspire innovation and participation in STEM for students at all levels and from all backgrounds.

This combination of innovative research and inclusive education has laid the groundwork for future advancements in soft robotics, with implications in exploration in extreme environments, human-robot collaboration, and medical/assistive applications.


Last Modified: 01/03/2025
Modified by: Cagdas D Onal
